results.title: Maggie Q Nourishes Herself With Local Produce and ‘Dateline’
results.abstract: The actress talks about her latest movie, “The Protégé,” her fascination with “American Gigolo,” her dedication to rescue dogs, and the joy of Asian stand-up and soup.

results.title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
results.abstract: The second round of funding for the year totals $28.4 million and will support 239 projects across the country.

results.title: Leos Carax on ‘Annette’ and the Cinema of Doubt
results.abstract: His movies often arrive amid a commotion, and his newest is no exception: “If you’re going to make a musical, you’ve got to be either ambitious or pretentious.”

multimedia.caption: Leos Carax on a restaurant terrace in New York. “A film is about putting your doubts and stupidity onscreen,” he said.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

results.title: Jennifer Hudson Knew Aretha Franklin. To Play Her, She Had to Learn More.

results.title: Clip by Clip, Showing Democracy Under Siege
results.abstract: The Times’s Visual Investigations team analyzed more than 3,000 videos to document, moment by moment, the terror of the Capitol riot.

results.title: Pat Hitchcock O’Connell, Director’s Daughter and Cast Member, Dies at 93
results.abstract: She acted in three films directed by her father, Alfred Hitchcock,  including “Psycho.” She later wrote a book about her mother’s role as his cinematic partner.

multimedia.caption: Patricia Hitchcock O’Connell, then known as Pat Hitchcock, with her father, Alfred, on the set of his film “Strangers on a Train” in 1950. She played a small role in this and two of his other movies.

results.title: Marcia Nasatir, Who Broke a Glass Ceiling in Hollywood, Dies at 95
